content.text: Determine the time taken for student Q to run 100 m
Determine the distance between the two students as Q reaches 100 m
Calculate the average speed of student Q during the \(100\mathrm{m}\) race
average speed =   .........  m/s
State which student has the faster speed between 3.0 s and 6.0 s
Explain how Fig. 1.1 allows you to compare speeds without calculation
Student P and student Q run in a \(100\mathrm{m}\) race
Fig. 1.1 shows the distance–time graph for each student during the race
Using the information in Fig. 2.1, determine the mass of the liquid in the beaker
The beaker contains \(750 \text{cm}^3\) of liquid
Calculate the density of the liquid
density =   .........  g/cm³
Calculate the weight of the empty beaker
weight =   .........  N
Fig. 2.1 shows a beaker containing liquid on a top pan balance
The mass of the empty beaker is \(400\mathrm{g}\)
Calculate the size of the resultant horizontal force on the car and state its direction
direction of resultant force
The driver presses the brake pedal and the car slows down
As the car slows down, the kinetic energy of the car decreases by \(100\mathrm{kJ}\)
Describe and explain what happens to this \(100\mathrm{kJ}\) of energy
Fig. 3.2 shows the force applied to the brake pedal by the driver's foot
Calculate the moment of the force about the pivot. Include the unit
Fig. 3.1 shows three horizontal forces acting on a car as it moves along a straight road
The horizontal forces act along the same straight line
The main stages in the operation of a coal-fired power station are listed below
They are **not** in the correct order
A The boiler produces steam
B The turbine turns a generator
C Thermal energy transfers to water in a boiler
D Chemical energy in coal transfers to thermal energy
E The generator produces electrical energy
F Steam turns a turbine
G Coal burns in a furnace
Complete the flow chart to describe how a coal-fired power station works
Insert the missing letters in the empty boxes
Some people are against the use of coal-fired power stations
Give **two** environmental problems caused by coal-fired power stations
the work done on each kilogram of coal
the output power of the motor
In the power station, a conveyor belt lifts coal from a coal supply to a furnace. An electric motor moves the conveyor belt. Fig. 4.1 shows this arrangement
The speed of the electric motor increases and the coal supply rate is increased. The conveyor belt lifts more coal each second. State the effect, if any, of increasing the motor speed on:
Electrical energy is provided to homes and industry from a coal-fired power station
The area of the steel container in contact with the bench is \(80 \text{cm}^2\). The total weight of the steel container and its contents is \(60 \text{N}\)
Calculate the pressure that the steel container exerts on the bench
pressure on the bench =   .........  N/cm²
Atmospheric pressure is equal to \(760 \text{mm}\) of mercury (mmHg)
Determine the pressure inside the container in mmHg
pressure =   .........  mmHg
The temperature of the gas inside the steel container decreases
State and explain how the pressure of the gas changes as the temperature of the gas decreases
Use your ideas about molecules in your answer
Fig. 5.1 shows a steel container fitted with a liquid manometer. There is a gas in the container
Fig. 6.1 represents three changes of state. Each pair of diagrams A, B and C shows the arrangement of molecules in a substance before and after it changes state
Give the term used for each change of state
A
B
C
A student attaches a liquid-in-glass thermometer to a ruler. The thermometer does **not** have a marked scale. Fig. 6.2 shows the arrangement
The student places the thermometer in steam. The mercury rises to 11 cm on the ruler
The student places the thermometer in melting ice. The mercury decreases to 1 cm on the ruler
Determine the temperature indicated by the mercury level in Fig. 6.2
temperature =   .........  °C
Determine the value of the angle of reflection for the ray of light at point X
On Fig. 7.1:
- draw the normal at point X and label the normal with the letter N
- draw the ray reflected from point X
Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of light incident on a plane mirror at point X
(not to scale)
Determine the focal length of the lens
focal length =   .........  \(cm\)
Determine the distance of the image from the lens
distance =   .........  \(cm\)
Describe the nature of the image formed by the lens in Fig. 7.2
Fig. 7.2 shows how a converging lens forms an image of an object
Fig. 7.2 (not to scale)
State the type of electromagnetic wave used for the mobile phone signal
The screen of the mobile phone emits visible light. State **one** type of electromagnetic wave with a shorter wavelength than visible light
State the range of audible frequencies for a healthy human ear. Include the unit
The ring tone of the mobile phone consists of two musical notes, note A and note B
Note A is louder and is higher in pitch than note B
Fig. 8.2 shows note A displayed on an oscilloscope screen
Note B is displayed on the same oscilloscope screen as note A. Describe the differences between the wave for note B and the wave for note A. You may draw on Fig. 8.2 to show the differences
The mobile phone produces sound waves
Fig. 8.1 shows a mobile (cell) phone
A student has a permanent bar magnet and two metal bars, as shown in Fig. 9.1
The student tests bar PQ and bar RS separately. He holds the N pole of the permanent bar magnet close to each end of each metal bar. Table 9.1 shows the results of the tests

table.html:
end of metal barresult of test with
N pole
Pattracted
Qrepelled
Rattracted
Sattracted

content.text: Deduce whether each metal bar is a magnet, an unmagnetised magnetic material or a non-magnetic material
Give a reason for each of your answers
1. metal bar PQ
2. metal bar RS
The student measures the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire XY
On Fig. 10.1, show the voltmeter correctly connected. Use the correct symbol
There is a current in the wire. State the name of the particles that flow through the wire
The student removes wire XY and replaces it with another wire CD. Wire CD is the same length and is made of the same material as wire XY, but thinner
State any difference between the current in wire CD and the current in wire XY. Explain your answer
State the unit used for the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery
The resistance of wire CD is \(8.7 \Omega\) and the resistance of the variable resistor is \(7.4 \Omega\)
Determine the combined resistance of the wire CD and the variable resistor
resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
The current in the variable resistor is 0.40A
State the current in wire CD
current =   .........  A
A student determines the resistance of a piece of metal wire XY
Fig. 10.1 shows the wire connected in the circuit
Determine the number of electrons
Determine the value of the nucleon number
Determine the number of neutrons
Fig. 11.1 represents the particles in a neutral lithium atom
Use the information in Fig. 11.1 about the lithium atom to answer (a)(i), (a)(ii) and (a)(iii)
The count rate of a radioactive sample is 2400 counts per minute at 10 am on one day. The half-life of the sample is two days
Predict the count rate at 10 am four days later
count rate =   .........  counts per minute
Fig. 12.1 shows two circuits, A and B, linked by a relay
Describe what happens in the two circuits when switch S is closed
Another circuit includes a transformer. The input voltage of the transformer is \(120\mathrm{V}\) a.c. The input coil has 480 turns of wire and the output coil has 60 turns of wire
Calculate the output voltage of the transformer
output voltage =   .........  V
